17.text:
So tonight I’m to talk to you about whether
or not koalas are in fact on the path to extinction.

23.text:
So we all recognise this beautiful creature
– it’s an icon of our country. People

28.text:
come here to see the koala, and if there’s
anyone notorious or famous in the media you

33.text:
can Google and find a relevant picture of
them holding a koala from some trip to Australia.

39.text:
These pictures are from the GO8 that was held
in Brisbane recently, and I think you’ll

43.text:
recognise why I chose the other one. And so
they’re an icon, they’re worth lots of

47.text:
money for our tourism trade, but they’re
also something that we really hold dear to

50.text:
our hearts. They’re very precious to us,
and so we need to take care of them, and I’m

54.text:
going to tell you about the dangers they face,
and particularly I’m going to tell you about

58.text:
the dangers they face from this really cute
looking little guy here. This is chlamydia,

64.text:
and chlamydia is one of the major threats
to the koala. So it looks kinda cute, but

68.text:
it doesn’t present that way to the koala,
so we’ll talk more about the chlamydia.

73.text:
But before I do that, the thing I always want
to do first is acknowledge the team. Science

78.text:
is not an individual game – science is a
team sport. In my lab there’s a lot of people

82.text:
who work in the lab, they work had, they work
long hours. Chlamydia’s hard to work on.

88.text:
And particularly Amber Lawrence in the middle
there did some of the really tricky experiments

91.text:
I’m going to tell you about, but also working
on koala is a very big team project. Vets,

98.text:
collaborators who are developing a chlamydia
vaccine at the Sunshine Coast, and medicinal

102.text:
chemists all played roles in this project.
And these are people from New Zealand, from

106.text:
the USA, from Stanford University, and we’re
supported by the Queensland Government for

110.text:
this project. So what is chlamydia? As I said,
it looks kind of cute, and in fact in these

117.text:
beautiful microscopy images that you can see,
it always looks really cute. We always think

122.text:
it’s green – it’s not really green,
but we stain it so it looks green. Chlamydia

126.text:
is a really ancient pathogen, so this tree
of life that you’re looking at on this side

132.text:
is a microbiologist’s view of life, so we’ve
excluded us from this tree. And what’s that

137.text:
telling you, where the chlamydia are coming
off there, that’s about 750 million years

141.text:
ago. So the chlamydia have evolved to live
inside our cells and inside the animal they

147.text:
infect’s cells for millions of years, and
that makes them really hard to treat, really

152.text:
hard to investigate and really hard to control.
On the top, what you’re looking at in the

157.text:
green in chlamydia pneumoniae from a koala.
This is a chlamydia pneumonia outbreak in

161.text:
a captive population in lone pine in the 90s.
All of that green, that’s the chlamydia,

170.text:
and what it’s doing is it’s overtaking
those red host cells. If you know anything

174.text:
about cells, you’ll see that it actually
looks bigger even than the host nucleus, so

178.text:
it really overtakes the cells of the organism
it infects. And the other pictures are chlamydia,

184.text:
environmental chlamydia infecting amoeba.
Chlamydia are actually everywhere – this

188.text:
is not a unique problem to the koala. I’m
not saying necessarily that Beyoncé and Jay-z

194.text:
have had chlamydia but they’re an example
of humans. So we see chlamydia everywhere,

198.text:
and generally the chlamydia have their own
particular hosts that they like to live in.

203.text:
But there’s a couple of exceptions, and
they’re the ones we’re going to talk about.

206.text:
Down the bottom here you can see chlamydia
pecorum, and it’s a major pathogen in farm

211.text:
animals but also in the koala, and they’re
quite different chlamydias. And also chlamydia

215.text:
pneumoniae, also a pathogen of the koala and
a whole range of different animals. The reason

220.text:
why chlamydia are so fascinating to work on,
but also so challenging, is because they live

225.text:
inside the cells of the organism that they
infect, as I mentioned earlier. They do that

229.text:
by having this extracellular spore-like form
that’s tough and transmits by contact or

234.text:
faecal-oral route, and then they co-opt that
cell and they take it over and replicate a

239.text:
lot inside that cell and then they go back
out again to re-infect. Now, how that presents

244.text:
as disease – I’ll tell you about the humans
first, because sadly we know a lot more about

248.text:
human chlamydia than koala chlamydia. If you
look at that eye, on that side for you, if

254.text:
you look at the eye, what you can see is little
white pustules, so the chlamydia are infecting

259.text:
there, and they’re causing an immune response,
and the eye is trying to clear that infection,

264.text:
but what it’s doing is it’s actually scarring
really severely, and so the eyelid turns over

269.text:
and condenses and those eyelashes rub on that
eye, and they rub and rub until the person

274.text:
goes blind, and that’s trachoma. There’s
about 5 million blind today from that disease;

280.text:
exactly the same disease happens in koalas
in the ocular tissue. The figure below that

285.text:
– this is a woman and this is her reproductive
tract, and what we’re doing is we’re looking

289.text:
from the outside with a type of x-ray, sonography,
and we’re putting a dye into her uterus.

295.text:
And you can see on one side the dye is flowing
out into her peritoneum, and on the other

299.text:
side the dye is not. So that same scarring
that you can see in the eye has happened in

304.text:
that tube. Now, for that woman, if that was
in both tubes, her only way to get pregnant

308.text:
would be by IVF. The same scarring happens
all throughout the urogenital tract of the

314.text:
koalas. In the koalas it’s even worse; it’s
a whole body of cysts and scars. It’s very,

319.text:
very painful. And so as I said, similar disease
spectrum in the koalas. To diagnose it in

326.text:
the koalas is quite tricky, because their
genital tract is very complicated and very

330.text:
internal. And one of the methods that we can
look at, and you can see this video yourselves,

335.text:
is sonography from the outside, a very special
machine developed for animals, and we see

339.text:
all this scarring and cysts all through their
urogenital tract. So what are we doing? So

345.text:
we’re trying – so many researchers are
working on this problem. We’re trying to

349.text:
develop better diagnostic techniques, and
this is a sedated koala from the wild that

353.text:
we’re testing for chlamydia, so those orange
swabs are our test for chlamydia. We take

357.text:
their blood to look at the immune response
to the chlamydia, and another group that I’ll

361.text:
mention are working on a vaccine to prevent
the chlamydia, but we also need to treat it.

370.text:
So as I said, we have a real problem with
chlamydia and koalas, but this problem is

374.text:
really a story about the lives that koalas
are leading in Australia right now. Koalas,

379.text:
whilst we all like to think of them as this
cute little guy here who’s having a nap,

383.text:
and we all think that’s what the koala does
– they just nap. In fact, koalas cover a

388.text:
lot of territory. They’re fussy, they like
very particular gum leaves in their environment,

393.text:
so they’ll travel to find the right gum
leaves, so that means they’re down on the

397.text:
ground a lot. As we build more roads and we
section off their habitat and as we build

403.text:
out into their environments, we put them under
stress. They move around a lot, they run out

407.text:
of trees to eat and they get hit by cars and
attacked by feral dogs. So the koalas is a

413.text:
whole spectrum of issues that we need to worry
about, and of course, the Australia Koala

417.text:
Foundation symbol of saving the trees. But
we need to think about the whole system when

422.text:
we talk about koalas, but importantly, and
my focus and my contribution, is a drug for

428.text:
koala chlamydia. As I said, it’s a very
severe disease. Here is a koala eye, and you

434.text:
can see just how inflamed and damaged that
eye is; that koala’s actually blind. If

438.text:
you’re a blind koala in the wild, your survival
rates aren’t good. At the top there, this

443.text:
is what we call ‘wet bottom’. This koala
has chronic incontinence from those chlamydial

450.text:
cysts all throughout the koala’s urogenital
tract. So we need a drug that’s more effective

462.text:
to treat the koala chlamydia. Sorry – I’ll
just have another drink. So why is that tricky?

474.text:
We’ve got lots of antibiotics, we all take
them throughout our life. Antibiotics for

478.text:
koalas are very, very tricky because the koala
lives on gum leaves. The koala will actually

485.text:
eat – here’s some gum leaves – the koala
will actually eat about 300-500 grams of these

490.text:
in a day, and the calorific content will be
less than two of these. So the koala has to

496.text:
digest these really complicated, not very
high calorie content leaves to get the energy

502.text:
it needs, but those are eucalypt leaves – they
also have a lot of toxins. So not only does

507.text:
the koala have to digest those leaves to get
the appropriate energy, it has to deal with

512.text:
a whole lot of eucalypt oil at a very concentrated
dose, [inaudible] and all sorts of toxic molecules.

518.text:
So that means there are two unique features
that we have to worry about when we try to

522.text:
make a drug for the koala. The koalas have
an amazing way to metabolise drugs, because

531.text:
of those toxins that it’s exposed to in
its diet. So most drugs are metabolised much

536.text:
more quickly by koalas than most other animals,
and because of the complexity of degrading

541.text:
those leaves, they actually have a two metre
long secum with a really complicated microbiome

546.text:
or mix of organisms that degrade those leaves.
And we need to preserve that. If we treat

552.text:
them orally with a classic antibiotic, that
microbiome can die and then the koala can

558.text:
effectively starve. So we have to treat them
with an intramuscular injection of an antibiotic

563.text:
called [name] every day for 45 days to cure
the chlamydia. It’s a long treatment regime,

569.text:
it doesn’t always work, but it’s the only
mechanism we have. Unfortunately there’s

575.text:
one company that makes that drug. The site
coincidentally that that was made at has been

580.text:
shut down. We have a very limited supply of
that drug left in Australia – a number of

586.text:
years. We haven’t found an effective alternative
yet. So that’s where my research comes in.

591.text:
We set out to use some of our human research
on a drug compound to develop a koala drug.

597.text:
In order to do that, we had to establish koala
chlamydial islet from clinical koalas, and

603.text:
here, again, in the red and green, the green
is the chlamydia over time, growing in cells

612.text:
at different time points, and there is an
ocular islet and urogenital clinical islets

616.text:
from diseased koalas. So we established a
mechanism to grow these islets and look at

621.text:
them. Then we took a drug that had come out
of our human research, or a lead compound,

626.text:
and we tested it against these islets. And
what you can see now is at different times

630.text:
when we add different doses the green inclusion
disappears. We call it an inclusion. The green

634.text:
sack of chlamydia disappears from the cell,
and we can statistically graph that over time.

640.text:
So our human compound looks like it works
in cell models to kill the koala. That was

646.text:
on two islets. We then got a whole collection
of clinical islets from Port Macquarie – the

650.text:
PMS, from southeast Queensland and from Lone
Pine from a captive animal, and we looked

655.text:
at ocular islets and urogenital islets and
dosed them over time with our drug. Now this

660.text:
is log scales – these graphs are actually
for every drop, you’re actually seeing one

665.text:
in 100 to one in 1000 to one in 10,000 drops,
so this is actually more substantial than

669.text:
it looks because it’s log scale. And so
our drug works really well to quite well on

674.text:
a whole range of clinical koala islets. So
this is the first time this many islets have

679.text:
been tested with any drug, in fact. And then
we went to the real innovation: we needed

684.text:
to prove that this worked in koala cells.
All the work around the world on koala chlamydia

692.text:
has been done using a mouse cell model. So
in conjunction with a whole consortium of

697.text:
people, we isolated koala cells from animals
that were having to be euthanised due to disease.

705.text:
One of them was a dog attack and one of them
had chlamydia. This is Bilbo and Natalie.

709.text:
This is picture of Bilbo and you can actually
see some evidence of the clinical conjunctival

713.text:
scarring around his eye. We isolated the cells
from these animals, from their conjunctiva,

718.text:
from their uterine tract, and for – in a
world first, we were able to grow those cells

723.text:
in the lab. This is the cells from Natalie,
not Natalia – Natalie’s uterus – over

729.text:
time. We were able to grow these cells, take
them out, look at the toxicity of our compound,

734.text:
the impact of our compound on the ability
of the cells to grow, and in a world first,

738.text:
infect those cells with chlamydia from koalas
and test our drug against it. And a stylised

745.text:
representation of our data – we did see
some toxicity in terms of the uterine cytotoxicity

751.text:
assay there of our compound, and we think
we need to work on that. We saw no impact

756.text:
on the proliferation, and we didn’t see
any toxicity on the conjunctival epithelial

760.text:
cells, and these were done in triplicate in
different tissue islets for the same two animals.

766.text:
In conjunction to that, animals that were
being vaccinated for the koala vaccine, which

771.text:
was many, many more – we were able to take
additional blood cells from those animals

775.text:
and in a much larger sample size of animals,
we didn’t see any toxicity on blood cells.

780.text:
So we’re getting there with the development
of this drug. It looks like it’s not toxic,

783.text:
or at least very low levels of toxicity that
will need improvement, and it’s quite effective

788.text:
in reducing the burden of koala in the cells,
so it is quite an effective antibiotic, in

791.text:
both a lab model but also importantly in real
koala tissue. And the final punch line is

799.text:
that we were able to re-infect that koala
tissue – that primary, lab-cultured koala

804.text:
tissue with chlamydia and prove in the dark
grey there that our compound was able to reduce

808.text:
the infection. So it works in koalas grown
in their natural cells.

815.text:
So that was very exciting, but we recognise
that we need to do further medicinal chemistry

819.text:
– so further drug development to make this
into a drug that we can actually do clinical

822.text:
trials with infected, diseased koalas. This
is a series of experiments that we did on

830.text:
conjunction with those medicinal chemists
that I mentioned at the start. So what I’m

834.text:
going to tell you about, if you look at this
molecule in the middle, that complicated sort

839.text:
of two-ring structure on the side, that’s
the mechanism of activity – that’s the

842.text:
kind of unique chemistry that this particular
molecule targets. In the middle is the specificity

849.text:
– how it knows where to bind – and on
the end, the chemists just kind of hand wave

854.text:
over that – it’s kind of a protective
group. So what we wanted to do was keep that

858.text:
specificity and improve the chemistry and
the pharmacokinetics, or the way that it stays

863.text:
in the tissue or gets to the tissue by working
on those two end groups. And just to reassure

869.text:
you that the specificity is real, by modifying
any of those three internal sites, we basically

874.text:
completely drop out the activity – so it
is very specific, the activity. And so by

879.text:
doing a series of experiments, and this molecule
over here is actually based on the HIV protease

886.text:
inhibitor that’s already in clinical use
for humans, and so we took that motif that’s

890.text:
already been in lots and lots of safety trials
for humans and changed our molecule. And it

895.text:
did drop the efficacy – it dropped the activity
a little bit, but it’s probably reduced

900.text:
the toxicity and that’s what we’re testing
right now. So it’s a balance between decreasing

904.text:
the toxicity but keeping enough activity.
Unfortunately some other attempts to improve

909.text:
the tissue penetration by modifying the other
end, the [inaudible], which I won’t try

913.text:
and say the full chemical names for, was not
as effective. But what our next phase now

918.text:
is to take another medicinal chemistry series
of products, test their ability to inhibit,

925.text:
and then text their efficacy and their toxicity,
both in the lab model but then back to the

929.text:
koala tissue model by working with our valuable
koala collaborators as well. And we think

934.text:
that it’s really a matter of another year
of medicinal chemistry approaches before we

938.text:
can actually be going into the animal model.
And it’s that urgent as well, so not only

942.text:
is it that the project is at that point, because
it’s actually that urgent because it appears

946.text:
that we have a 2-3 year window left of that
current drug, unless we come up with a new

950.text:
manufacture site, which hasn’t been easy
to do – it’s a very difficult drug to

954.text:
formulate. And so this may now be the solution
to koala chlamydia. So I think it’s possible,

961.text:
I think we need it, I think it may become
more and more pressing if we keep putting

964.text:
pressure on the koala habitat, the koala environment,
if we have another drought, if there’s other

968.text:
external pressures on those koalas, we will
need a lot of the drug. So I think it’s

973.text:
a real priority. I don’t think we can rule
out the vaccine. And that’s my collaborator’s

978.text:
work, and I think we do need a vaccine, but
koalas don’t come into the sexual health

981.text:
clinic for a check-up, even though we ask
them. This is how we vaccinate koalas in the

986.text:
wild. It’s not easy – it takes an amazing
crew of people to do it. I haven’t been

989.text:
on this field trip before. So we will always
need the antibiotic because we will never

994.text:
vaccinate all the koalas in the wild, so those
ones that come sick with the chlamydia, we

998.text:
will always need a new drug. So I think we
should be thinking about lots of aspects for

1003.text:
caring for the koala. So is the koala on the
path to extinction? I think if we don’t

1009.text:
address all of the factors in the environment
to help look after our koala population, I

1012.text:
think it is, and I think it’ll be a shame
if we’re the generation that’s responsible

1016.text:
for that. So I think there’s lots of things
you can do. I think that you can think about

1022.text:
your local environment – is there lots of
housing development going out into new habitats?

1025.text:
Do we need to do that? Can we live in smaller
environments to protect our environment? Are

1033.text:
there other ways that you can act sustainably
in your local environment? But if you think

1036.text:
you’d like to support the koala drug problem
as well, and our drug development activities,

1041.text:
then I’d like you to think about clicking
on the Giving at UTS website and our project,

1045.text:
which is A New Way To Save Koalas. And any
donations go directly to the project – there’s

1049.text:
no off the top cut for that, and it’s tax
deductible, so if you feel that’s an option

1053.text:
for you, that would be wonderful as well.
But even by being here and being interested,

1057.text:
you’ve done a lot for protecting our amazing,
iconic wildlife. Thank you.

1063.text:
Speaker 2: Good evening everyone. So this
is the northern quoll. I think it’s a beautiful

1070.text:
animal – it’s probably not as well known
as the koala, but the northern quoll, as the

1075.text:
name suggests, is found in northern Australia.
And this species once covered one third of

1080.text:
the top end of northern Australia. They were
really common and they were widely distributed

1084.text:
in savannah habitats. When I first went to
the Northern Territory back in ’96 with

1090.text:
my wife, we had the pleasure of camping at
Kakadu National Park, and it was a fantastic

1096.text:
place to go because it was teeming with wildlife,
so we set up camp and this is what we heard.

1104.text:
Barking owls, which are a really typical sound
of the top end.

1112.text:
And then we heard rustling outside the tent.
So we’d just gotten off to sleep, this great

1120.text:
rustling noise, so we went out to see what
that noise was, and of course, it’s a northern

1124.text:
quoll that had raided our esky and was eating
our chicken. And that was a really common

1130.text:
occurrence back in the 1990s. I mean, quolls
were everywhere. People in Darwin thought

1136.text:
they were a pest because they got in their
chicken coops and so on, and if you went to

1140.text:
Kakadu back in the late 1990s, you would have
seen quolls on the roads and bouncing around

1146.text:
campsites. So it was a fantastic place to
go and do biology.

1152.text:
Sadly, around 2000, 2001, there was a new
kid on the block – the cane toads. The cane

1159.text:
toads moved in from Queensland, they invaded
the Northern Territory, and they not only

1164.text:
sounded different to native frogs, but they
tasted different to. And they had these massive

1170.text:
toxin glands on their shoulders that had very
different chemicals that are found in native

1175.text:
frogs. And native predators, like goannas,
snakes and freshwater crocodiles, had no immunity

1182.text:
to toad toxins, so when these predators attacked
or bit a cane toad, they got a lethal dose

1188.text:
of toxin, and we saw massive population declines
of predators as toads invaded the Northern

1194.text:
Territory. Unfortunately one of the animals
that was most heavily impacted by cane toads

1200.text:
was the northern quoll. Quolls are really
interesting because they’re short-lived

1205.text:
animals. Females only live two or three years.
Males only live about one year if they’re

1211.text:
lucky. They, in the mating season they run
around trying to mate with as many females

1215.text:
as they can, they travel huge distances in
a night – six or seven kilometres – and

1221.text:
not surprisingly they get really run down
during the mating season and then they keel

1225.text:
over and die. So you end up with a population
composed mostly of females, and when the toads

1232.text:
invaded, these females saw the toads as a
great food source, they attacked and they

1238.text:
died, and the young were left defenceless
in the den, and the populations collapsed.

1244.text:
Luckily the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife
saw this collapse happening – they were

1251.text:
monitoring populations in Kakadu, so they
trans-located 64 quolls from Kakadu to two

1258.text:
offshore islands off [name] – Astell Island
and Pobassoo Island, and established an insurance

1264.text:
population off the coast to insure that the
species didn’t go extinct. After they did

1272.text:
this, populations kept collapsing on the mainland,
quolls became very rare, and n 2005 the Federal

1278.text:
Government declared the species as federally
endangered, and they’re now listed as critically

1284.text:
endangered in the Northern Territory. Cane
toads are amazing dispersal machines. The

1293.text:
toads at the invasion front are travelling
at a rate of about 60 kilometres a year, which

1298.text:
is incredible for a big frog to hop that far
in one wet season. The toads are now poised

1305.text:
to invade the Kimberly – they’ve already
invaded places in the Kimberly like [name]

1311.text:
station, and we’ve already seen quoll populations
decimated in those areas, and eventually the

1317.text:
toads will invade the last two strongholds
of the northern quoll: the Kimberly populations

1323.text:
in the central and western Kimberly, and the
Pilbara. And if the models of toad distribution

1330.text:
are correct, then in the next 20 years, the
toads are going to make their way through

1335.text:
the Kimberly, and eventually they’ll invade
the Pilbara region. There’s not much we

1342.text:
can do to stop the spread of cane toads; we
know they’re going to invade the Kimberly

1346.text:
pretty soon, but we might be able to do something
to protect quoll populations and stop them

1352.text:
going extinct. The major problem if you’re
a quoll and you encounter a cane toad is the

1359.text:
toads at the invasion front are these really
big toads that have got there first – they’re

1365.text:
amazing dispersal machines, so the first toads
that quolls encounter are these large toads

1372.text:
that have lots of toxin, and these are killer
toads. The quolls don’t have a chance. When

1377.text:
they bite or mouth one of these toads, they
get a lethal dose of toxin and they die. They

1383.text:
don’t get a chance to learn. However, after
toads invade, they breed, and there’s lots

1390.text:
of little toads, and I’d been working on
some smaller marsupials that are really just

1395.text:
miniature quolls – things like planigales
and dunnarts. And I was interested to see

1400.text:
if these animals could learn to cope with
cane toads, and what I discovered was dunnarts

1406.text:
and planigales, when they see little toads
they grab them, they think they’re good

1410.text:
to eat, they start chewing on them and then
they feel sick, so they discard the toads

1416.text:
and they never touch them again. So this is
what happens when a planigale that’s eaten

1428.text:
There’s no way he’s going to eat that
toad. And this is called condition taste aversion.

1441.text:
And any of you out there that have had food
poisoning will know exactly how this works.

1445.text:
I guarantee you that if you get sick tonight,
and you spend the night throwing up and I

1451.text:
put the food that made you ill in front of
you in the morning, you’ll push it away

1454.text:
and go ‘There’s no way I can eat that.’
And condition taste aversion is a really powerful

1459.text:
form of learning. It was discovered in the
1970s and when it was first discovered, people

1465.text:
didn’t believe that it could work, because
it only requires one bout of poisoning for

1473.text:
you to remember not to eat that food and to
develop a long-term aversion, and this is

1477.text:
quite different to classical conditioning
where you need multiple trials to learn, so

1481.text:
it’s quite a different form of learning.
So I did some research about condition taste

1488.text:
aversion and discovered that way back in the
1970s, conservation biologists had discovered

1494.text:
condition taste aversion and they used it
as a tool to train predators not to eat certain

1500.text:
foods. And one of the classic trials was on
coyotes that were eating sheep in America,

1506.text:
and what the researchers did, which was really
smart, was they fed the coyotes a bait laced

1513.text:
with a nausea-inducing chemical, so they gave
the coyotes some lamb with a nausea-inducing

1518.text:
chemical. The coyotes ate it, they threw up,
they then put the coyotes in a pen with the

1524.text:
lambs. The coyotes chased the lambs because
they thought they were good to eat, and when

1529.text:
they got close the coyotes gagged and left
the lambs alone. And there’s this classic

1534.text:
video of the lambs chasing the coyotes around
the pen.

1540.text:
Now, field trials with coyotes weren’t successful,
so the technique got forgotten – everyone

1546.text:
forgot about condition taste aversion, but
I read this research and thought well, perhaps

1551.text:
we can use this tool to train quolls not to
eat cane toads. So I had a meeting with Deon

1558.text:
Wedd and Damien Staniock at the territory
wildlife park, and they had a captive colony

1563.text:
of quolls that was an insurance population,
and I talked to them about this project that

1569.text:
I wanted to get off the ground, and I basically
said to them ‘Can I come and make your quolls

1574.text:
sick?’ And the carers at that meeting said
‘No’. Which wasn’t surprising – the

1580.text:
carers didn’t think the quolls could learn
to avoid eating cane toads, so I had to wait

1585.text:
about a year before some new quoll carers
came on board. Deon rang me up and said ‘Do

1591.text:
you want to give that project a go?’ And
I said ‘Yeah, I’d love to give it a go.’

1594.text:
So my honours student Stephanie O’Donnell
and I went back to the wildlife park and we

1600.text:
trialled this technique using condition taste
aversion. So what we did was we had a vet

1606.text:
standing by, because we weren’t sure what
size toad we could feed a quoll without killing

1612.text:
it, and we gave them a small dead toad paired
with a nausea-inducing chemical called [name]

1617.text:
that’s been tested on livestock and mammals
– it’s really safe to use – and lo and

1623.text:
behold, the quolls ate the toad, they got
mildly sick, but what happened next was really

1630.text:
exciting: these toad-smart quolls refused
to eat cane toads. So this is one of the quolls

1635.text:
from that study that Stephanie O’Donnell,
my honours student, did, and you can see the

1639.text:
quoll’s really interested in eating that
cane toad, because it’s giving out all the

1644.text:
signals that quolls normally associate with
something good to eat. The toad’s jumping

1648.text:
around, it looks good to eat, but you can
see the quoll’s really using its sense of

1653.text:
smell to identify whether that’s palatable
food or not, and you can see the quoll’s

1659.text:
not eating that cane toad, which was really
amazing for us, because we’ve witnessed

1665.text:
quolls eating toads, you know, with disastrous
results, and here’s a quoll that’s just

1672.text:
getting frustrated and taking it out on our
camera equipment.

1683.text:
So we’re really excited about the prospect
of using this technique to train quolls not

1689.text:
to eat cane toads, so the next step in the
project was we fitted quolls with radio collars

1694.text:
so that we could locate them daily, and Stephanie
enlisted a large team of volunteers and she

1700.text:
released toad-trained and controlled quolls
in areas near Darwin, and she monitored their

1707.text:
survival, and what she found was really exciting:
you can see here we’ve got toad-smart quolls

1715.text:
with males and females, and toad-naïve quolls,
and the take-home message is our toad-smart

1720.text:
quolls had much higher survival than our toad-naïve
quolls, and you can see that males were more

1728.text:
And that’s not really surprising. So that
research really was the impetus to the research

1736.text:
that we’re currently doing, so that was
proof of concept that perhaps this technique

1740.text:
could work – maybe we could help save the
quolls. So what we’re doing now with this

1745.text:
collaborative project is we’re aiming to
try and reintroduce toad-smart quolls to Kakadu

1751.text:
to see if we can help those populations to
recover in areas where quolls are locally

1756.text:
extinct, and the second project is much more
ambitious, and it’s largely being done by

1762.text:
one of my PhD students, Naomi Walters, with
the Australian Wildlife Conservancy, and Naomi

1768.text:
is going to attempt to try and prevent quoll
extinctions from occurring by putting out

1773.text:
toad aversion sausages ahead of the toad invasion
front, which I’ll come to a bit later in

1778.text:
the talk. So the first project has been up
and running for quite some time now, and the

1786.text:
aim was really to see if we could bring quolls
back to areas where they’re locally extinct,

1790.text:
so this work was done up in Kakadu National
Park up in northern Australia. If you haven’t

1796.text:
been to Kakadu yet, I think you should put
it on your bucket list. It’s a great part

1800.text:
of the world. It’s just a fantastic place
to work. So what we did was we reintroduced

1806.text:
toad-smart quolls to an area near Ubirr, near
East Alligator River in 2009 and 2010, and

1814.text:
this is what the study site looks like – it’s
on the edge of the Arnhem Land escarpment.

1819.text:
It’s savannah woodland interspersed with
rock outcrops – it’s a beautiful part

1823.text:
of the world. And it has a fantastic art site
called Ubirr, which – and this is the view

1830.text:
that you get looking out from the Ubirr escarpment
onto the East Alligator floodplain. It’s

1835.text:
just a magnificent part of Australia, there’s
some fantastic Aboriginal art, and I think

1840.text:
the nice thing about working in this part
of Kakadu is the Aboriginal people are still

1844.text:
very much engaged in managing the land and
they’re still doing traditional rock art

1849.text:
and traditional ways of hunting and so forth.
And there’s some really amazing art – does

1854.text:
anyone know what that beast is? I’ll give
you a hint: it’s got stripes. Yeah, it’s

1860.text:
a thylacine – it’s a Tasmanian tiger.
So Tasmanian tiger’s were present in the

1866.text:
top end of northern Australia roughly 5 or
6000 years ago before the dingoes invaded.

1872.text:
So what we do to monitor quolls is we put
out these cage traps with a bait of peanut

1880.text:
butter, honey and oats – I have no idea
why that bait works and why it’s used by

1884.text:
mammal biologists, but that’s the bait that
everyone uses, and we catch lots of really

1889.text:
amazing animals like short-eared rock wallabies,
you can see in the left here, and rock rats

1894.text:
on the right, and we also catch quolls, which
is our target animal, and I’ve put this

1901.text:
slide up, not because we were sponsored by
Qantas – it would have been nice to be sponsored

1905.text:
by Qantas but they lost Tim’s luggage. But
they did give him a shirt that he got to wear

1915.text:
What we do when we’re working on our mammals
is we microchip every animal that we catch,

1921.text:
so every animal’s got a little microchip
similar to what you put in your cat or your

1924.text:
dog on the scruff of the neck, and because
we wanted to know if each generation of quolls

1931.text:
would learn to avoid eating cane toads, we
took tissue samples from all the toad-smart

1936.text:
females that we re-introduced, and also from
any offspring that we caught. And our geneticist,

1941.text:
Peter Spencer at Murdoch University, was then
able to use the tissues and the DNA to work

1946.text:
out who the mums and dads were of all the
animals in this population. And this is just

1953.text:
showing how we release the animals – we
just let them go in a crevice after we’ve

1960.text:
finished processing them. Okay. So when we
started this work, there was only one female

1966.text:
left in this population, so it wasn’t a
terribly healthy population. We knew from

1971.text:
the work Mary Oakwood did on this population
that it used to have roughly 30 females. When

1977.text:
toads came through, it crashed down to two
or three, and it was on a path to extinction.

1983.text:
We then introduced our 22 toad-trained females.
Six of these females survived long term and

1991.text:
reproduced, and not surprisingly, the population
increased, which was exactly what we were

1997.text:
hoping for. And I guess the really exciting
thing for us was that we saw recruitment of

2001.text:
juveniles – the green bars on that graph
– into the population. And so we’re really

2008.text:
excited about these results. When Peter Spencer
looked at the genotypes of all the animals

2013.text:
in the population, he found that roughly two
thirds of the animals in this population were

2019.text:
direct descendants of those toad-trained females.
And that was really exciting for us, because

2023.text:
it means that each generation of quolls learns
how to avoid eating cane toads. And that’s

2030.text:
really important if we want to use toad sausages
ahead of the toad invasion front, because

2035.text:
it means we only have to do it once, because
thereafter the quolls will learn to avoid

2041.text:
eating cane toads. How do juvenile quolls
learn not to eat cane toads? That was the

2050.text:
question we were really interested in. We
had no idea how they’d learn that toads

2054.text:
were not good to eat. My PhD student Tegan
Cremona put radio collars on quolls as they

2062.text:
were leaving mum’s dens, and she radio tracked
them to try and find out what they were doing.

2067.text:
And what Tegan did that was really innovative
was she put remote cameras near the dens of

2075.text:
quolls that had left home, and also their
mother’s den, to see if there was any ongoing

2080.text:
interactions between mothers and offspring.
So the traditional wisdom about quolls that

2085.text:
everyone told us was that quolls are solitary
– there’s no capacity for social learning.

2092.text:
But what Tegan found was really exciting:
by putting these cameras out, she saw lots

2095.text:
of wildlife like the rock wallaby. These are
rock ring-tailed possums that live in family

2100.text:
groups – amazing animals. What Tegan found
that was these quolls that had left home came

2108.text:
back to their mothers dens. So just like humans
that have left home, the quolls come back

2114.text:
and raid their parents’ pantries and go
foraging with mum. And so what we think’s

2121.text:
happening is we know that toad-smart mothers,
when they encounter toads, they sniff and

2125.text:
reject them as you saw on that video. Juveniles
are clinging on mum’s back when she’s

2130.text:
out foraging – they’re probably watching
mum sniff and reject toads on a nightly basis.

2135.text:
Any of you that have got kids will know that
if you want your kids to eat healthy food,

2141.text:
you have to eat that food because your kids
will copy what you do, right? So if I want

2145.text:
my kids to eat fruit, I have to eat lots of
fruit. So we think that quolls probably learn

2151.text:
what to eat by watching what mum eats. Now,
if mum doesn’t eat something, the quolls

2156.text:
are probably not going to eat it either. So
we know quolls can learn to avoid eating toads.

2165.text:
Unfortunately they’re still not really common
in this area where we reintroduced them, and

2170.text:
we think the reason for this is that the country’s
burnt too frequently, and this burning every

2176.text:
year in Kakadu that’s been occurring opens
up the habitat and it really allows predators

2182.text:
like dingoes and feral cats to prey on quolls
and that’s exactly what we’ve found. When

2188.text:
Tegan was tracking her juvenile quolls, she
discovered that dingoes were the major predator,

2194.text:
and feral cats were also a major predator.
So in a nutshell we think we could probably

2203.text:
bring quolls back, but we’re going to have
to manage the country a lot better than we

2207.text:
have been if we want to do this. So what we
found was toad-smart females survived and

2214.text:
reproduced in this population. We know that
each generation can learn not to eat cane

2220.text:
toads, so what we’re hopeful of is that
we should be able to bring quolls back to

2225.text:
areas where they’re locally extinct by reintroducing
these toad-smart quolls that we’ve trained

2230.text:
not to eat toads, but if we’re going to
do that we really need to manage fire, because

2234.text:
that’s the biggest problem we’ve got right
now in northern Australia. Okay, so I’m

2239.text:
going to change track now and I’m going
to take you over to the central Kimberly to

2245.text:
Mornington Wildlife Sanctuary where Naomi
is currently working, and the aim of Naomi’s

2252.text:
project is to see if we can actually prevent
some of these population declines from occurring.

2257.text:
So this is Sir John Gorge at Mornington – it’s
a beautiful part of the world. It’s one

2262.text:
of the, I guess, the most pristine landscapes
that I’ve been to. It’s just magical at

2270.text:
this time of the day. And the good thing about
Mornington is there’s still lots of wildlife

2276.text:
that you can see, so as a biologist it’s
one of my favourite places to go and visit.

2282.text:
This is a water monitor, and these are brolgas
that I saw dancing when I was out there last

2288.text:
time, so just a fantastic part of the world
to work in. This is Naomi. So Naomi is in

2298.text:
the first year of her PhD. Naomi’s attempting
to train wild quolls not to eat cane toads,

2303.text:
and she’s doing that by putting out toad
sausages at baited and controlled site and

2309.text:
the aim is to see if she can keep quolls in
the system at those baited sites. Now, if

2314.text:
that project works, we’re then going to
upscale and do helicopter delivery of bates

2319.text:
over bigger areas, but we’ve got to start
small and just see if the technique will work.

2325.text:
Lots of people ask me how we make toad sausages
– well, it’s just a lot of hard work.

2329.text:
You get your dead cane toads, you chop off
their legs; the legs are non-toxic. You can

2335.text:
then put the legs through a blender and make
a really nice sausage that is apparently quite

2341.text:
palatable, so if you were desperate you could
probably put it on the barbecue. Once we’ve

2347.text:
made the sausage, we put it out under a camera
and the reason for doing this is we need to

2353.text:
know whether quolls will eat the baits, and
also whether there’s non-target species

2359.text:
that might also eat the baits, so we need
to know that. Here’s a photo from one of

2364.text:
Naomi’s cameras – you can see a quoll
inspecting a toad sausage, and the really

2369.text:
nice thing about using the cameras is you
can actually identify individual quolls from

2373.text:
their spot patterns. So you can look at these
photos and you can work out exactly which

2379.text:
quoll has eaten a sausage, and by doing this
we’re hoping to see whether the quolls that

2384.text:
eat sausages are the ones that survive after
the toads invade. So far Naomi’s trials

2394.text:
have been really promising. She’s found
that 50 per cent of quolls at her study sites

2399.text:
have eaten the toad sausages. We know from
trials we’ve done in the lab that quolls

2405.text:
that eat sausages get sick – we’re hoping
they’ll avoid eating cane toads when they

2409.text:
come through. Naomi’s deploying baits this
coming wet season, around November. She doesn’t

2417.text:
have much time – I just talked to Naomi
today, and unfortunately the toads have moved

2423.text:
further than we thought this wet season, and
they’re only 20 kilometres from her study

2428.text:
site, so she’s literally got a couple of
months to try and protect this population

2433.text:
before the toads invade. We’re really strapped
for staff – we have been well funded by

2446.text:
various granting agencies, but we don’t
have enough money to employ a research assistant,

2452.text:
and Naomi’s doing this work on her own with
volunteers, and we could really use your support

2458.text:
if you want to help prevent quoll extinctions
and you feel like supporting this research,

2463.text:
grab one of the fliers on your way out. Any
support would be really welcome to help us

2470.text:
trial this technique in the Kimberly. Just
to finish, I took my family back to Kakadu

2477.text:
this year – these are my kids and my wife
– dragged the family up there 20 years after

2482.text:
I first went there with my wife, and we went
camping and we heard the barking owls at night

2489.text:
when we were in our tents. We heard rustling
in the leaf litter – we went out there to

2494.text:
look and we didn’t see any quolls. My kids
wanted to see what the rustling noises were,

2500.text:
and so I took them out and we got our torches
out and they were cane toads. We didn’t

2505.text:
see any small mammals, and the sad thing is
that small mammals, not just quolls, are declining

2511.text:
all over the top end. We’ve now got a third
extinction event going on. Small mammals are

2516.text:
disappearing from pristine areas like Kakadu
National Park at an alarming rate, and this

2523.text:
is a tragedy. And we think that too-frequent
burning of the landscape, loss of Aboriginal

2529.text:
management with fire and introduced predators
are really knocking our small mammals around.

2536.text:
So feral cats are probably playing a really
big role in this recent decline, but it’s

2542.text:
also possible that disease is involved. This
is really saddening for me to see mammals

2550.text:
that were once common in Kakadu 20 years ago
disappearing before our eyes, and I think

2555.text:
it’d be really sad if the only small mammals
our kids see are at the territory wildlife

2562.text:
park or zoos. This would be a tragic loss.
So I think just to sum up, we really need

2567.text:
to look after our country better for future
generations. Thanks for listening.
